text:
Welcome to how to cook that
I am Ann Reardon

Today at the top of the request list is red
velvet cake.

There are many variations on red velvet cake
recipe and I am going to share with you my
recipe for it.

When I was in new york last year I did my
own self guided tour of bakeries and pattiseries.

If you're heading to new york you can read
about that on the blog.

Every cupcake store I went to said red velvet
cake was their best selling cupcake, so that

is what I purchased in between goodies from
al the other stores and the cupcakes ranged

from tasting just like a vanilla cake died
red with a buttercream icing which was a bit
disappointing.

through to ones with a rich cream cheese frosting
and a beautifully but distinct flavoured cake

- and that is what I want to recreate for
you today.

I've experimented using varoius recipes some
that use buttermilk and vinegar and none of

these gave that special flavour that I loved
in new york.

I even tried making them with red velvet emulsion
that I bought but when I checked the ingredients
it was basically just a bottle of red colouring.

And so then I discovered this key ingredient
that gave the flavour I was after which morello
sour cherries.

What we are going to do is take your jar or
cherries and strain the juice into a saucepan.

You can use the cherries themselves in another
dessert later.

And then we want to concentrate the juice
so that we can concentrate the flavour so

we are going to boil it allowing the water
to evaporate off until we are left with only

1/2 a cup or 125ml . So if you pour it off
and you've got too much put it back in the
pan and boil it a bit more.
Then leave that to cool completly.

Measure out your flour and take out 2 tablespoons
of the flour then add back in two tablespoons
of cocoa powder.
Pour that into a bowl with the sugar.

Now all the ingredient quantities that you
need for this recipe are listed on the website

howtocookthat.net there's a link in the description
just below this video.

Add in your baking powder, your salt and your
gelatin.

I am using the gelatin in this recipe as an
emulsifier which what that does is helps the
oil and water to mix together well.

If you can't have gelatin you could leave
it out but I like the texture of the cupcake
better with it in.

Whisk those ingredients together this is just
the same as sieving it so it's adding air
and getting rid of any lumps.
Then make a well in the centre.
Seperate your eggs into the yolks and whites.

if you are new at doing this them I suggest
you use a new bowl for each egg white so that

if you get a tiny bit of yolk in there you
haven't spoiled all the whites you've only
spoiled one.

Even just a little bit of egg yolk is going
to stop your egg whites whipping up so you'll

have to put the egg aside for something else
and use another one.

Add your yolks and your oil onto the flour
mixture.

Then pour over the concentrated morello cherry
juice, now don't mix this up just put this
bowl to one side.

In a seperate bowl add your egg whites and
cream of tartar and whip the egg whites until
you get soft peaks that look just like this.

Then using those the same beaters mix the
other bowl of ingredients on low speed until
they are just combined.

Now if you want your cupcakes to be bright
red like at the shops you have to add red
colouring and stir that through gently.

Nest we want to fold our egg whites into the
cake mixture and to do that we are going to

do it in three batches so add some of it in
and use your spatula to fold going around

underneath and back over the top not just
around the edges.
Make sure you are going underneath.

ANd by doing ti in three batches it allows
us to keep the maximum amount of air into

our mixture which will give us lighter fluffier
cupcakes.

Using a soup ladle pour some of your cupcake
mixture into each cases so that they are 3/4
full

and once you've done that place them in the
oven for 11 minutes or until they just bounce

back when you gently press them on top with
your finger.

Set them aside and allow them to cool completely
before you frost them otherwise it's going

to melt the frosting and it's just going to
slide off.

You can make your cream cheese frosting using
the video and recipe that I have already given

you I will link to that in the description
below and also annotate that here.

Place it into a ziplock bag and then reinforce
the corner with some tape.

Make one cut in the centre of the corner and
then flatten the bag out so that the cuts

you've just made are on the edge and make
an identical cut in the middle, this will
give you a nice pattern as you pipe.

I'll just show you that again on an envelope
so you can see what I was doing so just one

cut in the middle turn it around and flatten
it and one cut in the middle on the other
side.

Pipe generous swirls of frosting onto each
cupcake, my frosting recipe is a little less

sweet than traditional cream cheese recipes
which is how I like it.

Then you can just sprinkle the top of each
one with a little bit of red sugar.

And you are ready to eat these delicious red
velvet cupcakes that taste just like the ones
I had in NYC

Now when you make some of these make sure
you post a picture up to instagram and #howtocookthat

or put it int the comments section on the
blog I love seeing what you guys make.

And next weeks we have a dessert then chocolate
then back to cake so put your requests in
the comments below.

There's has been some requests for a question
and answer video so if you have some questions

you'd like me to answer you can chuck those
in the comments just put a Q&A with it so
I know it's for the video.
Thanks and I'll see you all next week, Bye.
[music the boat song by setsailtv]
